response_metadata.response_text:
{
"overview": "The purpose and intent of this measure is to appropriate funds for housing initiatives and establish a supportive housing fund (HB431_SD1). The bill appropriates funds to the Office of the Governor for the \"continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). It also appropriates funds to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) for the \"development of supportive housing projects and provision of supportive services for certain households\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"appropriations": "This measure contains unspecified appropriation amounts (HB431_SD1). The legislative document inserts a blank appropriation amount for the \"continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1) and a blank appropriation amount to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). Testimony from HHFDC requests $175,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist position to help administer the provisions of the bill (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"assumptions_and_methodology": "The measure contains unspecified appropriation amounts, and as such, detailed financial projections are not provided (HB431_SD1). The Committees have requested that the Office of the Governor provide the amounts necessary for the implementation of the programs for further deliberation (HB431_SD1). The only specific cost component identified is a request from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for $175,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) to fund a new permanent staff position based on anticipated administrative workload (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"agency_impact": "The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) states it \"supports HB 431 HD2 SD1\" and anticipates needing additional resources to manage the program (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). HHFDC requests $175,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time equivalent housing finance specialist position to administer its new responsibilities (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The Department of Human Services supports the measure but requests that any appropriation align with the executive budget and not reduce or replace other budget priorities (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"economic_impact": "Testimony from the Office of the Governor states that \"by providing housing for chronically homeless individuals will not only improve overall health outcomes but will also help to save taxpayers millions of dollars in health care costs\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The State Council on Developmental Disabilities notes the bill will \"reduce reliance on costly institutional care or emergency services, and improve overall health, social inclusion, and quality of life for individuals with I/DD\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). This measure is intended to \"expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State\" (HB431_SD1).",
"policy_impact": "The Committees have amended this measure by \"Deleting language that would have allowed funds appropriated for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1). The measure also deletes language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund, instead inserting a blank appropriation to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). It also deletes language that would have set procurement requirements for kauhale projects estimated to be over $1,000,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) (HB431_SD1).",
"revenue_sources": "The provided documents do not explicitly state the revenue source for the appropriations in this version of the bill. However, testimony regarding a previous version of the measure refers to a \"general fund appropriation\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). Typically, unspecified state appropriations are drawn from the general revenues of the State.",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "Although the bill contains unspecified appropriations, testimony provides context for potential funding levels. The legislative document notes the ohana zones pilot program initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt), with subsequent appropriations of $15,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) and $5,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) for extensions (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt). Testimony from the Office of the Governor indicates the Governorâ€™s Executive Biennium Budget requested $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) million each year for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation has requested recurring funds for a permanent staff position, seeking $175,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time housing finance specialist (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The purpose of the funds is for the \"development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services\" (HB431_SD1), indicating significant and ongoing costs for both capital development and operations over the next six years. The Governor's goal is to establish 30 kauhale villages across the state by the end of 2026, suggesting an acceleration of expenditures if funded (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). These recurring costs for operations, maintenance, and supportive services will continue for the life of the housing projects.",
"operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents for this version of the measure do not identify any anticipated impacts on operating revenues.",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure appropriates a blank amount for the \"development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects\" (HB431_SD1), which implies significant capital expenditures for construction. Funding is also appropriated for the \"continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program,\" which involves establishing housing sites (HB431_SD1). Testimony regarding the Kauhale Initiative describes the development of \"communal villages of tiny homes,\" another form of capital expenditure (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications after six years would consist of ongoing operational costs for the housing projects developed under the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. These recurring costs include maintenance, management, and the provision of supportive services for residents. The request for a permanent FTE position by the HHFDC indicates that administrative costs are also expected to be permanent and ongoing (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This fiscal note is updated to reflect significant amendments to the measure. A key change is the deletion of language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund; this is replaced with a direct blank appropriation to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). The measure no longer contains policy requirements for kauhale projects to be connected to public utilities or for rent charges to be capped, which were included in the previous version. Furthermore, this version separates funding streams by inserting distinct blank appropriations for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and HHFDC's supportive housing projects, whereas the prior version was more consolidated (HB431_SD1). The expending agency for the Ohana Zones program appears to remain with the Office of the Governor, differing from the previous note which indicated a shift to the Department of Human Services."
}

"overview": "The purpose and intent of this measure is to appropriate funds for housing initiatives and establish a supportive housing fund (HB431_SD1). The bill appropriates funds to the Office of the Governor for the \"continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). It also appropriates funds to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) for the \"development of supportive housing projects and provision of supportive services for certain households\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",
"appropriations": "This measure contains unspecified appropriation amounts (HB431_SD1). The legislative document inserts a blank appropriation amount for the \"continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1) and a blank appropriation amount to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). The State Council on Developmental Disabilities notes the bill will \"reduce reliance on costly institutional care or emergency services, and improve overall health, social inclusion, and quality of life for individuals with I/DD\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). This measure is intended to \"expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State\" (HB431_SD1).",
"policy_impact": "The Committees have amended this measure by \"Deleting language that would have allowed funds appropriated for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program\" (HB431_SD1). The measure also deletes language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund, instead inserting a blank appropriation to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). It also deletes language that would have set procurement requirements for kauhale projects estimated to be over $1,000,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) (HB431_SD1).",

However, testimony regarding a previous version of the measure refers to a \"general fund appropriation\" (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). Typically, unspecified state appropriations are drawn from the general revenues of the State.",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "Although the bill contains unspecified appropriations, testimony provides context for potential funding levels. The legislative document notes the ohana zones pilot program initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt), with subsequent appropriations of $15,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) and $5,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) for extensions (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt). Testimony from the Office of the Governor indicates the Governorâ€™s Executive Biennium Budget requested $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) million each year for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation has requested recurring funds for a permanent staff position, seeking $175,000 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time housing finance specialist (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). The purpose of the funds is for the \"development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services\" (HB431_SD1), indicating significant and ongoing costs for both capital development and operations over the next six years. The Governor's goal is to establish 30 kauhale villages across the state by the end of 2026, suggesting an acceleration of expenditures if funded (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_). These recurring costs for operations, maintenance, and supportive services will continue for the life of the housing projects.",
"operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents for this version of the measure do not identify any anticipated impacts on operating revenues.",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure appropriates a blank amount for the \"development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects\" (HB431_SD1), which implies significant capital expenditures for construction. Funding is also appropriated for the \"continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program,\" which involves establishing housing sites (HB431_SD1). Testimony regarding the Kauhale Initiative describes the development of \"communal villages of tiny homes,\" another form of capital expenditure (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",

These recurring costs include maintenance, management, and the provision of supportive services for residents. The request for a permanent FTE position by the HHFDC indicates that administrative costs are also expected to be permanent and ongoing (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_).",

A key change is the deletion of language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund; this is replaced with a direct blank appropriation to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects (HB431_SD1). The measure no longer contains policy requirements for kauhale projects to be connected to public utilities or for rent charges to be capped, which were included in the previous version. Furthermore, this version separates funding streams by inserting distinct blank appropriations for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and HHFDC's supportive housing projects, whereas the prior version was more consolidated (HB431_SD1). The expending agency for the Ohana Zones program appears to remain with the Office of the Governor, differing from the previous note which indicated a shift to the Department of Human Services."

chunk_details.chunk_text: JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR DEAN MINAKAMI EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND TOURISM HAWAII HOUSING FINANCE AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 677 QUEEN STREET, SUITE 300 HONOLULU, HAWAII 96813 FAX: (808) 587-0600 Statement of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before

of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before the SENATE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS March 28, 2025 at 10:02 a.m. State Capitol, Room 211 In consideration of H.B. 431 HD2 SD1 RELATING TO HOUSING. Chair Dela Cruz, Vice Chair Moriwaki, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports

Vice Chair Moriwaki, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports HB 431 HD2 SD1, which appropriates funds to the Office of the Governor for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program. It also appropriates funds to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) for

to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) for the development of supportive housing projects and provision of supportive services for certain households in the supportive housing projects. HHFDC supports the measure so long as it does not adversely impact priorities identified in the Executive Budget Request for FY

impact priorities identified in the Executive Budget Request for FY 2026. HHFDC recognizes the need for a dedicated funding source to assist individuals with special needs. The appropriation will allow us to develop, operate, and maintain affordable, supportive housing projects and provide supportive services for households with special needs who

and provide supportive services for households with special needs who reside in such projects. We request $175,000 for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help administer the provisions in Section 5 of the bill. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. AN

you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. O. Box 339 Honolulu, Hawaii 96809-0339 March 27, 2025 RYAN

O. Box 339 Honolulu, Hawaii 96809-0339 March 27, 2025 RYAN I. YAMANE DIRECTOR KA LUNA HOÊ»OKELE JOSEPH CAMPOS II DEPUTY DIRECTOR KA HOPE LUNA HOÊ»OKELE TRISTA SPEER DEPUTY DIRECTOR KA HOPE LUNA HOÊ»OKELE TO: The Honorable Senator Donovan Dela Cruz, Chair Senate Committee on Ways and Means FROM: Ryan I.

Chair Senate Committee on Ways and Means FROM: Ryan I. Yamane, Director SUBJECT: HB 431 HD2 SD1 â€“ RELATING TO HOUSING. Hearing: March 28, 2025, 10:02 a.m. Conference Room 211 & Videoconference, State Capitol DEPARTMENTâ€™S POSITION: The Department of Human Services (DHS) supports this measure, which invests in the Kauhale

Services (DHS) supports this measure, which invests in the Kauhale initiative, the Ohana Zones Pilot program, and permanent supportive housing as strategies to reduce homelessness. DHS defers to the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions (SOHHS) and the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC). DHS respectfully requests that

Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC). DHS respectfully requests that any appropriation align with the executive budget and not reduce or replace other budget priorities. PURPOSE: The bill appropriates funds to the Office of the Governor for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program. Appropriates

of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program. Appropriates funds to the HawaiÊ»i Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the development of supportive housing projects and provision of supportive services for certain households in the supportive housing projects. Effective 6/29/3000. (SD1) The House Committee on Human Services & Homelessness

6/29/3000. (SD1) The House Committee on Human Services & Homelessness amended the measure by: (1) Changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts; March 27, 2025 Page 2 AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY AGENCY (2) Deleting language that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of a general fund appropriation at the end of the

of a general fund appropriation at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation was made; (3) Deleting language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund; (4) Inserting language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing

the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative; (5) Changing the effective dates to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, respectively, to encourage further discussion; and (6) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. The Committee on Housing further

of clarity, consistency, and style. The Committee on Housing further amended the measure by: (1) Expanding the authorized uses of funds appropriated for the Kauhale Initiative; (2) Authorizing funds appropriated for the Kauhale Initiative to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of

Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018; (3) Requiring at least two bidders for any Kauhale project estimated to be over $1,000,000 if appropriated funds are used to contract for the procurement of building services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative; (4) Deleting the

and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative; (4) Deleting the unspecified appropriation to the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions to implement the Kauhale Initiative; and (5) Making technical, nonsubs

SSCR1287 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1287 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 431 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committees on Health and Human Services and Housing, to which was referred H.B. No.

Human Services and Housing, to which was referred H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," beg leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize

for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize those funds to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program; and (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. Your Committees received testimony in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance

in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation; State Council on Developmental Disabilities; Department of Human Services; Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions; Office of Hawaiian Affairs; Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of Hawai Ê» i; Office of Housing of

the County of Hawai Ê» i; Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu; Hawai Ê» i State Youth Commission; Catholic Charities Hawai Ê» i; Hawai Ê» i Health & Harm Reduction Center; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Maui Chamber of Commerce; Hawaii Young Adults in Transition; Hawai Ê»

Chamber of Commerce; Hawaii Young Adults in Transition; Hawai Ê» i Community Foundation; Pacific Housing Assistance Corporation; Hawai Ê» i Appleseed Center for Law & Economic Justice; Easterseals Hawaii; Young Democrats of Hawai Ê» i; Democratic Party of Hawai Ê» i; The Institute for Human Services, Inc.; and four individuals.

i; The Institute for Human Services, Inc.; and four individuals. Your Committees received comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance and State Procurement Office . Your Committees find that to meet the State's needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is

solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Your Committees further find that both the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale

that both the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative aim to provide supportive housing and services with an emphasis on community-based solutions. This measure provides funding for the continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative, in addition to funding for the Hawaii Housing

Kauhale Initiative, in addition to funding for the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services, to further expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout

for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State. Human Services and Housing, to which was referred H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," beg leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize

for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize those funds to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program; and (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. numbers_data.text: Budget Request for FY 2026. HHFDC recognizes the need for a dedicated funding source to assist individuals with special needs. The appropriation will allow us to develop, operate, and maintain affordable, supportive housing projects and provide supportive services for households with special needs who reside in such projects. We request $175,000 for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help administer the provisions in Section 5 of the bill. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY AGENCY JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR KE KIAÊ»Ä€INA STATE OF HAWAII KA MOKUÊ»Ä€INA O HAWAIÊ»I DEPARTMENT

the authorized uses of funds appropriated for the Kauhale Initiative; (2) Authorizing funds appropriated for the Kauhale Initiative to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018; (3) Requiring at least two bidders for any Kauhale project estimated to be over $1,000,000 if appropriated funds are used to contract for the procurement of building services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative; (4) Deleting the unspecified appropriation to the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions to implement the Kauhale Initiative; and (5) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity,

Studies have shown that by providing housing for chronically homeless individuals will not only improve overall health outcomes but will also help to save taxpayers millions of dollars in health care costs. We are very grateful for the previous support of the Legislature appropriating $33 million for kauhale for Fiscal Year 2025 and we respectfully ask for your favorable consideration once again to fund this program. to save taxpayers millions of dollars in health care costs. We are very grateful for the previous support of the Legislature appropriating $33 million for kauhale for Fiscal Year 2025 and we respectfully ask for your favorable consideration once again to fund this program. This potential funding will help to continue to allow the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions to continue its important work and will also help to achieve the Governorâ€™s goal of establishing 30 kauhale villages across the state by the

2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure

legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the

extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual,

to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless

to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities".
